title: 110_hr2544
content: The "Independent Ethics Commission Act of 2007" establishes an Independent Ethics Commission. The Independent Ethics Committee, established by the "Independent Ethics Commission Act of 2007," consists of 9 commissioners appointed by the Speaker and minority leader for 5-year terms. Commissioners must be former Federal judges, and no lobbyist can be appointed. Members of the Commission must not have been lobbyists within the 4-year period before appointment. They cannot be Members of Congress. Vacancies are filled as per original appointment method. Members receive compensation based on the Executive Schedule Level III rate. A majority of members constitutes a quorum. The Commission requires a majority of members for a quorum and meets when called by a majority of its members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF COMMISSION. The Commission is authorized to receive, monitor, and oversee financial disclosure and other reports filed by Members of the House, investigate alleged violations of conduct rules, present ethics violation cases to the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, and make recommendations for reporting violations to appropriate authorities. The Office of Congressional Ethics oversees compliance with laws and standards of conduct for House of Representatives employees, provides guidance on rules and regulations, and considers requests for formal advisory opinions on conduct. The Office of Congressional Ethics provides guidance on rules and regulations for House of Representatives employees and considers requests for formal advisory opinions on conduct. Members, officers, and employees can seek advice and publish opinions for the guidance of others. SEC. 4. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, issue subpoenas with majority approval, request information from government agencies, refer potential violations to the Department of Justice, and conduct general audits. The Commission has the authority to conduct general audits of filings under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. SEC. 5. INVESTIGATIONS AND INTERACTION WITH THE HOUSE COMMITTEE ON STANDARDS OF OFFICIAL CONDUCT. The Commission must notify the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct when it decides to conduct an investigation. The committee can overrule the Commission's determination within 10 legislative days with a two-thirds majority vote and must provide a public report explaining their decision. Members who disagree can issue their own report. If overruled, the Commission can publish the decision. The Commission may conduct investigations if it determines sufficient grounds exist, and can issue subpoenas, administer oaths, and compel witness testimony. Non-compliance may result in contempt of Congress. If the Commission concludes an investigation, the case is presented to the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. The Commission notifies the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct if probable cause of an ethics violation is found. The committee can overrule the Commission's determination with a two-thirds majority vote within 10 days, issuing a public report explaining their decision. If overruled, the Commission can publish a report on the case. The Commission notifies the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct if probable cause of an ethics violation is found. The committee votes on whether the individual violated rules, with dissenting members able to issue their own report. Sanctions are recommended if a violation is found. The Commission recommends sanctions to the committee and may refer matters to the Department of Justice for investigation. SEC. 6. PROCEDURAL RULES. The Commission cannot report on or investigate the official conduct of a House of Representatives member, officer, or employee without majority approval. Investigations can only be initiated by a written complaint from a House member or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. No investigation can be conducted on alleged law violations. The Commission cannot investigate alleged violations of laws, rules, regulations, or standards of conduct that were not in effect at the time of the alleged violation. Information or testimony received, complaints, or filing details cannot be publicly disclosed without Commission authorization. The Commission may appoint staff and determine their compensation. The Speaker and minority leader jointly appoint the Commission, and members are paid at a rate not exceeding Level III of the Executive Schedule. Amendments to the House rules may change the duties of the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. House Rules Amendments: Clause 3 of rule XI of the Rules of the House of Representatives is amended to redesignate subparagraphs and strike certain paragraphs. Conforming Amendments are made to Section 803 of the Ethics Reform Act of 1989. Upon receipt of a report by the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, the Speaker of the House of Representatives will have it printed in the Congressional Record. Within 14 days of the report being printed, any recommendations for action regarding alleged violations by a Member, officer, or employee will be introduced as a resolution by the Speaker and minority leader, constituting a question of privilege under House rules. Any Member supporting the resolution can bring it up as a question of privilege, but only on the third day after announcing their intention to do so. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will be effective upon enactment, with exceptions for sections 3, 4, and 8 which will not take effect until noon on January 3, 2009.
